SAC Report Knocks Down
President's Discipline Code
By MICHAEL HILL
The -Student Affairs Committee has
issued its report on student discipline, a
report that differs significantly from the
proposals set forth by President Gordon
at the beginning of the year.
Members of the Student Affairs Committee have been studying the discipline
question since September when the reports of an ad hoc committee and Gordon's revised proposals were sent to them
for consideration and revision.
Now that the committee has sent
back its report, it is not known whether
it will be adopted. Gordon has also requested comments on his discipline proposal from the administrative heads of
the other divisions of the University. They
have all sent back recommendations, however, what effect these will have on his
final decision is not clear.
Their report begins by defining con:
duct which might require discipline as
that which "abridges the right; of other
individuals or groups, especially as it
affects the educational goals of those
within the University community, or
threatens their safety, health or property,
or conduct that causes damage to physical facilities of the University."
"Normal Functioning"
These categories are considerably
narrower than those proposed by the
'President. Students would not be sanctioned for disrupting "the normal functioning of the University" as the committee found that phrase from Gordon's report to "have no substantial and specific
meaning and thus was liable to be applied
to any situation which some particular
section of the University "found offensive."
In an appendix to its report, the
committee enumerated the reasons for
most of the changes made. It was made
clear that the student-faculty group felt
that various groups in the University
would inteipret "normal functioning" differently.
Moreover, the Committee removes
Gordon's proposal for sanctions against
- "conduct that significantly impairs the
effective relationship of the University to
the larger community of which it is part."
The Committee felt that this area was
covered "in a way that was far less open
to misinterpretation..."
Further, the Committee states that
"the University will not intrude itself into
the personal lives of its students nor will
it add sanctions for unlawful behavior
already dealt with by civil authority, unless such behavior falls within the class of

conduct described above." This phrase
was included in the original proposal of
Gordon's original Discipline Committee.
Review Board
The remainder of the report is concerned with setting up a Review Board
to consider any major punishments incurred by students. Punishments would
be limited to suspension under the proposal, with no mention of expulsion,
which was included in Gordon's state. ment.
The Review Board iS composed of
two undergraduate students, two graduate
students, two faculty members and one
administrator. This adds two more students than Gordon's proposal. The members will be chosen by random selection.
This board would conduct a trial of
any student sanctioned by suspension,
with the power to sustain, increase or
decrease the punishment or to exonerate
the student.
Emergency Situations
This section significantly differs from
Gordon's recommendations on one point,
the procedure in case of -an emergency.
Under Gordon's proposal, if the administration felt that an emergency situation
existed, it could apply immediate sanctions, with the Review Board considering
the sanction after the fact.
The new proposal has the Review
Board convening "by the next day" in an
emergency situation, instead of the usual
rule of "within five days."
Bob Cotter, president of the Graduate Student Organization, and member of
the Committee on Student Affairs, disagreed with the designation of any situation as an emergency one. He felt that
if the situation was not one .in which the
police should be called in, then the normal procedures should be used. He felt
that this emergency provision allowed the
administration to avoid a confrontation.
He said this does not offer "any way of
exerting pressure by means of civil disobedience."

Boycotters Forced Back to PE —Maybe
By PETER HARNIK
Although the question of mandatory
Physical Education has been re,solved for
the majority of this year's Freshmen,as
well as for all future freshman classes,
the problem of what will happen to the
students who boycotted gym during the
first semester has yet to be settled.
As of Wednesday night, the Committee
on Student Affairs maintained its decision
that the elimination of compulsory PE
not be retroactive. The letter of protest
sent by Freshman President David
Charry this week to Dean Swanson, was
rerouted to the Student Affairs Committee. It will be brought up at next Wednesday's meeting. If it is rejected, the
boycotters will have to face another semester of gym.
Although the freshmen maintain that
there was no clear policy boycott and
no recruitment for the action, approximately 130 of them signed a "complicity statement," indicating that they
were not attending gym classes. Unofficial figures indicated that 140 students
failed physical education for the first
semester.

White Vehement
At the same time, Dr. John White,
Chairman of the Committee on Student
Affairs, vehemently denied that the boycott was responsible for the ultimate
settlement of the issue. "The action only
hurt the cause," he stated. "The three
students who brought in the petition handled the situation correctly. We then reacted to them properly by having our

Athletic Subcommittee look into the matter. That is what committees like Student Affairs are for."
A petition asking for an end to compulsory gym and a general upgrading of
the physical education program was signed by 370 Freshmen and delivered to
Dean Swanson's office on October 6.
Swanson officially forwarded the petition to the Student Affairs Committee
on October 29, and from there it went
to the Permanent Subcommittee on Athletics.

"No Muddle"
"The power structure between committees is unclear," White admitted,
"but there was no muddle about this.
Swanson wrote that his committee (the
Committee on Undergraduate Studies)
was not competent in the area of athletics, and we had a subcommittee that
was. It's as simple as that." The Athletic
subcommittee was set up in September as
a • result of faculty complaints that the
physical education program did not leave
them enough time .slots for adequate use
of the gymnasium.
On November 20, during a meeting with
David Charry, Jim Owens and various
other leaders of the movement, the subcommittee was informed of the boycott
action. Dr. Jackson Cope, chairman of
the subcommittee, remarked that he was
"surprised" by the move, and thought
that the signers were "exerting undue
pressure" upon a committee which was
in the process of coming to a conclusion.
"I told them I though that the second
petition made a strange bedfellow with

the original one, and that those who had
signed both were being rather inconsistent," he explained.
Mr. Charry maintains that the Freshmen resorted to staying away from gym
classes because they were afraid that
otherwise the subcommittee would take
its time on reaching a conclusion and
that the question would remain unresolved into the second semester. "It would
never have been decided had there been
no pressure," he claimed.
"Look," he continued, "the subcommittee is heavily weighted toward the
Physical Education Department.The boycott stopped the stalling. It wasn't aimed
against the committee--just against the
subcommittee." Besides Cope, the subcommittee consists of Coach Alex Sotir,
Director of Athletics Marshall Turner,
graduate student Richard Barchi, and
undergraduates John Hammond and Paul
Allen.
Dr. Cope disagreed with Mr. Charry's
analysis. "If you're asking whether the
second document (the boycott) had any
effect on either the committee or the subcommittee, the answer is `no'."

Plan Rejected
On December 10 the subcommittee's
full plan for athletics, including one semester of compulsion, was released to
White's committee and promptly rejected. "For me," White said, "the (subcommittee's) advice didn't prove acceptable enough to demand compulsion."
The committee then decided to abolish

the requirement, but not to make it retroactive to September, 1969. "As far as
explained,

still have it to do. Denying due process

In Charry's view, this is "circuitous"

Hopkins Losing $3 Million; Digs Into Capital
Johns Hopkins will lose $3 million this
fiscal year, $1 million more than estimated by University officials when the budget
was formulated last May.
According to Robert Kerley, VicePresident for Administration, a "substantial" portion of the deficit will be paid
by the University's quasi-endowment
capital funds. He defined "substantial"
as about 80%, or $2.4 million, of the loss.
The 1969-70 budget exceeds $125 million,
including the Applied Physics Laboratory's $50 million budget.

Conscious Policy
This was the second straight year that
Hopkins has dipped into its capital reserves to break even. in 1968-69, the
University ran $500,000 in the red. The
budget has shown a $200,000 to $300,000
profit in past years.
President Gordon claimed that the deficit in the past two years was a conscious policy of the Board of Trustees.
"We decided we would rather run a temporary loss than cut back programs," he
remarked. However, due to expected increases and government research cuts,
this year's budget will run $1 million
more in the red than anticipated by the
Trustees last spring.
The same policy will be in effect for
Hopkins' finances in 1970-71. Kerley
stated that last Wednesday the Trustees Budget Committee decided to adopt
"a conscious budgeting of the operating
deficit by dipping into quasi-endowment
funds."

"The coming budget is going to have to
go up because of inflation,' he noted.
Nevertheless, Dr. William Bevan, VicePresident and Provost, said, "It will be
an exceedingly tight year. There's no
secret about that."
Dr. Gordon maintained that Hopkins
was not alone in its financial plight. He
called the financial erosion of the country's private universities a "serious
and nationwide problem."
The President cited three major reasons why Hopkins is losing money: the
cutbacks in federal grants to universities, the rise in wages for nonprofessional workers and the inflationary spiral
that has increased all expenditures.

Cutbacks and Increases
Government-financed research has
been on the decline for the last few years
at Hopkins. According to Bevan, this is
because Hopkins has ended much of its
Department of Defense (DOD) contracts,
and government officials have recently
been dissatisfied with basic research at
universities compared to applied reDOD conindustries.

tracts have dropped as a percentage of
the University's total research monies
from 18% to 8% in the past five years.
Foundations, led by the Ford Foundation, also have become discouraged with
projects sponsored by the nation's
universities, said Dr. Bevan. He noted

that many local community action groups
are now being funded by foundations.
The National Institute of Health and
National Science Foundation fellowship
grants have declined drastically.In 1967,
there were 95 NIH fellowship awards.
There may be none this year. There
have also been major cuts in NSF grants
and contracts.
In December Congress passed a bill
providing $1 billion more for the Health,
Education, and Welfare budget than President Nixon requested. The money, $134
million which would go to universities,
was vetoed by President Nixon last week.

Unless Congress overrules the President, Hopkins will be among the losers.
Gordon estimated that if wage increases for Hopkins' nonprofessional
employees follow the agreement reached
at the Johns Hopkins Hospital, it will cost
the University $500,000 more than anticipated from January to June 1970,and
$1.5 million additional in the 1970-71
budget.
Faculty salaries have been rising with
inflation at a rate of about 6-8% in past
years, and the President expects the increases to continue. Building costs are
now rising 11-13% each year.

As this school year began, it was generally agreed that governance
was the most important issue confronting the school's various decisionmaking bodies. Rumblings of dissatisfaction over Homewood's antiquated and clumsy decision-making processes emanated from many segments
of the community.
Dr. George Owen proposed last September a University Senate which
would represent students, faculty and administrators. At the time, we
supported the plan, and the Student Council and the Graduate Student
Organization both sent letters to Dr. Gordon, advocating the creation of a
University Senate. Dr. Owen's plan was submitted to the Academic
Council and has been sat on for four months. The Academic Council's
committee-to-appoint-the-committee-gambit effectively forstalled any significant action to this point. The Student Council has held grandiose
"tactics sessions," created a committee and reassured its constituents of
its "firm stance." The Graduate Student Organization has issued similar
statements and done equally little.
In short, students seem content to "let the matter go through channels," and it seems not to matter that the channels are clogged with the
sewage of "professorial courtesy," face-saving and misleading verbiage. It
is time students realized that nothing is being done about governance, and
that nothing will be done this year if the Academic Council is allowed to
proceed at its own pace. It is not to the advantage of the faculty to
change the system of governance at Homewood. As it stands, faculty
wishes are unhindered by annoying student demands. It is unrealistic to
suppose that the faculty will act with all possible speed to deprive itself
of its privileged status.
Last year, students at Homewood demonstrated that they could
force the system to respond to legitimate demands. It seemed to the
Academic Council and the administration that calendar reform could not
possibly be enacted in time for the fall term of the present school year.
A militant stance by students quickly convinced the policy makers that
calendar reform was not only feasible but necessary.
This week, Dr. Woodford Howard stated that the March deadline
for his committee's report is "unrealistic." However, if the March deadline is not met, governance reform will not be possible by next year.
Dr. Howard's committee is charged with determining whether "widespread dissatisfaction" over governance exists. Presumably they will take
into account whether dissatisfaction exists among the students. It is indicative of the faculty's attitude toward' the S.C. and G.S.O. that it did not
interpret their letters as showing student dissatisfaction.
The faculty may believe that if student opinion were united in dissatisfaction with governance, much more would have been heard from
student representatives. Certainly, these representatives should do more
than send one letter affirming their "firm stance." As a first step, they
might poll those they represent to see if the dissatisfaction exists. If it
does, they should be prepared to exert as much pressure as possible to see
that governance is not let slide another year.

the democrats in Congress.
Analysis of the speech reveals much the

entire Nixon performance to date: a lot

crime and the quality of the environment. In meeting these two challenges,
the President said, there can be no rigid
partisanship.
When he came to the first issue of

desegregation orders.

But crime is not going to stop, and the

The Court System
The court system in Baltimore has all
but collapsed. The city is nearly bankrupt,

in this city is probably the most antiquated and understaffed one of any major
metropolitan area in the nation. From

Baltimore's outdated system of justice

Baltimore's court system is supposed
to run like this: After a man is arrested for a crime, he must be brought to
one of nine Municipal Courts for a preliminary hearing. At this level, the
arresting officer presents the charge,
and on the rare occasions the judge thinks
there are no grounds for the case, it is
dismissed. But usually, if it's a misdemeanor (maximum penalty no more than
3 years and/or fine of $1,000) trial will
be set for a later date before the Municipal Court judge. On the other hand, if
it is a felony or the suspect requests a

is handed down to the Criminal Court,
the suspect is arraigned, and a trial
date is set. The time between the preliminary hearing and the arraignment is
at least a month, and often more.

Guns, No Butter
Red China has begun an austerity drive designed to
heighten military preparedness and, at the same time,
improve her economic condition.
Using the threat of war with the Soviet Union, which
is believed to be causing genuine concern among authories, Chinese leaders are trying to unite the people in
their goal to conserve resources. Many analysts feel that
the main purpose of the drive is to strengthen the economy
which has suffered from corruption and black-market
activities. Reduced consumption of coal, petroleum and
electricity has already been achieved, according to
reports.

leave the country has had an effect on world prices. The
stockpiling of grain and other resources by localities is
being urged by Peking officials to create self-sufficient
areas which could play vital, strategic roles in cases of
foreign invasion.

700,000,000 Chinese but it has cut expenses by 6%.

Johns Hopkins will lose $3 million this

This was the second straight year that
Hopkins has dipped into its capital reserves to break even. in 1968-69, the

profit in past years.

remarked. However, due to expected increases and government research cuts,
this year's budget will run $1 million
more in the red than anticipated by the
Trustees last spring.

Hopkins' finances in 1970-71. Kerley
stated that last Wednesday the Trustees Budget Committee decided to adopt
"a conscious budgeting of the operating
deficit by dipping into quasi-endowment
funds."

go up because of inflation,' he noted.

an exceedingly tight year. There's no
secret about that."

was not alone in its financial plight. He
called the financial erosion of the country's private universities a "serious
and nationwide problem."

cutbacks in federal grants to universities, the rise in wages for nonprofessional workers and the inflationary spiral
that has increased all expenditures.

been on the decline for the last few years
at Hopkins. According to Bevan, this is

As this school year began, it was generally agreed that governance
was the most important issue confronting the school's various decisionmaking bodies. Rumblings of dissatisfaction over Homewood's antiquated and clumsy decision-making processes emanated from many segments
of the community.
Dr. George Owen proposed last September a University Senate which
would represent students, faculty and administrators. At the time, we
supported the plan, and the Student Council and the Graduate Student
Organization both sent letters to Dr. Gordon, advocating the creation of a
University Senate. Dr. Owen's plan was submitted to the Academic
Council and has been sat on for four months. The Academic Council's
committee-to-appoint-the-committee-gambit effectively forstalled any significant action to this point. The Student Council has held grandiose
"tactics sessions," created a committee and reassured its constituents of
its "firm stance." The Graduate Student Organization has issued similar
statements and done equally little.
In short, students seem content to "let the matter go through channels," and it seems not to matter that the channels are clogged with the
sewage of "professorial courtesy," face-saving and misleading verbiage. It
is time students realized that nothing is being done about governance, and
that nothing will be done this year if the Academic Council is allowed to
proceed at its own pace. It is not to the advantage of the faculty to
change the system of governance at Homewood. As it stands, faculty
wishes are unhindered by annoying student demands. It is unrealistic to
suppose that the faculty will act with all possible speed to deprive itself
of its privileged status.
Last year, students at Homewood demonstrated that they could
force the system to respond to legitimate demands. It seemed to the
Academic Council and the administration that calendar reform could not
possibly be enacted in time for the fall term of the present school year.
A militant stance by students quickly convinced the policy makers that
calendar reform was not only feasible but necessary.
This week, Dr. Woodford Howard stated that the March deadline
for his committee's report is "unrealistic." However, if the March deadline is not met, governance reform will not be possible by next year.
Dr. Howard's committee is charged with determining whether "widespread dissatisfaction" over governance exists. Presumably they will take
into account whether dissatisfaction exists among the students. It is indicative of the faculty's attitude toward' the S.C. and G.S.O. that it did not
interpret their letters as showing student dissatisfaction.
The faculty may believe that if student opinion were united in dissatisfaction with governance, much more would have been heard from
student representatives. Certainly, these representatives should do more
than send one letter affirming their "firm stance." As a first step, they
might poll those they represent to see if the dissatisfaction exists. If it
does, they should be prepared to exert as much pressure as possible to see
that governance is not let slide another year.

By ARTHUR LEVINE
In November, 1965, Robert Moore was
charged with robbery with a deadlyweapon and placed in the Baltimore City Jail.
Today, he is still awaiting trial. There
are now more than 300 people who have
been in the City Jail for more thanthree
months and up to two years awaiting trial.
And there are almost 7,000 criminal indictments that still haven't been tried.If
all crime ceased tomorrow,it would take
more than thirteen months to dispose of
these thousands of criminal indictments.
But crime is not going to stop, and the
situation is deteriorating rapidly: For
every two cases that are moved out of
the system, three new ones come in.

The Court System
The court system in Baltimore has all
but collapsed. The city is nearly bankrupt,
and the result is that the court system
in this city is probably the most antiquated and understaffed one of any major
metropolitan area in the nation. From
the office of the State's Attorney of Baltimore City, which is in charge of prosecutions, to the seven full-time judges
of the Criminal Court, the effects of
Baltimore's outdated system of justice
are becoming all too obvious.
Baltimore's court system is supposed
to run like this: After a man is arrested for a crime, he must be brought to
one of nine Municipal Courts for a preliminary hearing. At this level, the
arresting officer presents the charge,
and on the rare occasions the judge thinks
there are no grounds for the case, it is
dismissed. But usually, if it's a misdemeanor (maximum penalty no more than
3 years and/or fine of $1,000) trial will
be set for a later date before the Municipal Court judge. On the other hand, if
it is a felony or the suspect requests a

jury trial, the case is sent up to the Grand
Jury for consideration.In an overwhelming majority of the cases, an indictment
is handed down to the Criminal Court,
the suspect is arraigned, and a trial
date is set. The time between the preliminary hearing and the arraignment is
at least a month, and often more.

Students Run Health Information Center
In an effort to provide essential information about health services available to
the East Baltimore community, students
at the Hopkins School of Medicine and
School of Nursing are operating a voluntary Community Health Advocacy Program (CHAP).
Upon request, Baltimore residents can
receive advice as to which local health
facility would best serve their particular
health problem at the lowest cost and
least inconvenience. Whenever necessary CHAP will make the appointment,
escort the person to the agency and help
with the forms.
People who have received some type
of health service before contacting
CHAP, and who have found dissatisfaction with some aspect of their care,
may register their complaint and have it
investigated.
According to Daryle B. Matthews, a
Year III medical student and originator
of CHAP, "the role of coordinator of
care, the
role
of providing well
researched
information is something
which is totally vacant in our present
health service. The role of advocate is
more strongly needed as you travel down
the ladder of the socio-economic scale."
CHAP's philosophy revolves around
service intended to avert the possible
consequences resulting from complex,
fragmented, impersonal health care.For
instance, through the efforts of the
CHAP personnel, a woman was saved a
$700 hospital bill which charged her for
special duty nurses she had neither approved of nor been consulted about.
Other, CHAP services range from
informing people about their rights under
Medicare and Medicaid to directing a

college student on a bad drug trip to
the best medical facility available.
CHAP was organized last summer by
a group of eight students after it was
approved by the administration of the
Medical , School. A $10,000 grant from
a private foundation was awarded to
finance the program, Presently, there
are about 20 medical and nursing students operating CHAP.
CHAP is the only community-oriented
project undertaken by medical students.
Most volunteers view this effort as a
test of their interest and ability in organizing and running a program not totally
dependent upon Hopkins' support. Workers feel that CHAP is indicative of a
trend in the medical and nursing schools
toward increased involvement in political
areas. "There are some of us who view
ourselves as activists with leftist tendencies, although this is less prominent
here at Hopkins than at most places,"
said a student volunteer.
Matthews admits that CHAP has been
having some difficulty in providing adequate publicity about the program.
Efforts have been made in coordination
with local Community Action Agencies to
reach those living in government housing
projects in the inner-city. Other plans
for future publicity include working with
community school personnel and ministerial alliances of local church groups.
CHAP is now operating out of a rowhouse office at 709 Rutland Avenue.Facilities are provided by Hopkins Hospital
and share with the Drug Abuse Center
located in the same building.

B and M Held Up
Three armed robbers entered the B and M Subshop,
rifled the cash register and robbed five customers of
over $100 last Saturday night.
As the men were leaving one was frightened by a noise
from one of the freezers (the one with ice-cream in it)
and fired his gun at the younger Joe Bataglia, but the
weapon mis-fired and no injury was incurred.
According to Joe, two of the men entered the shop at
about 10:30 p.m. and looked around before going outside.
They came back about an hour later with another man,
forced all the customers into the back room and made
Joe and Salina stand behind the meat counter.
Joe said that when he called in the robbery to the police, he was still talking to the receptionist as officers
arrived on the scene. He also claimed that the heist was
very well planned with one man standing by the door and
another holding a gun on those in the store. The third
took the money.
According to an News Letter editor, Joe makes "the
best meat-ball sub in the world." Another claims that
he is the "finest sub maker in the business."

Guns, No Butter
Red China has begun an austerity drive designed to
heighten military preparedness and, at the same time,
improve her economic condition.
Using the threat of war with the Soviet Union, which
is believed to be causing genuine concern among authories, Chinese leaders are trying to unite the people in
their goal to conserve resources. Many analysts feel that
the main purpose of the drive is to strengthen the economy
which has suffered from corruption and black-market
activities. Reduced consumption of coal, petroleum and
electricity has already been achieved, according to
reports.
The reluctance to allow steel and tungsten ore to
leave the country has had an effect on world prices. The
stockpiling of grain and other resources by localities is
being urged by Peking officials to create self-sufficient
areas which could play vital, strategic roles in cases of
foreign invasion.
The leader in the economy drive has been the army.
By saving on building materials and fuel, and by innovating frugal practices like sterilizing used bandages for
further use, the army has not only set an example to the
700,000,000 Chinese but it has cut expenses by 6%.

Spiro the Hero
It seems that America's emerging hero, according to
Time Magazine, is Spiro Agnew.
The man who bumbled his way through the 1968 campaign and was then the laughing stock of the nation has
now assumed the role of world statesman and spokesman
for middle America. It is no wonder that jokes have begun
to circulate about Agnew's dropping Nixon from the 1972
ticket and that bumper stickers and posters glorifying
the Vice President are popping up all over the nation.
He is a top attraction for speaking engagements, and,
just recently, he was accorded the honor in the Gallup
Poll of being rated as the third most admired man in
America. There is little doubt that the man who spoke
out against the news media and protesters reflects the
attitude of a vast segment of the population.
Republican Party leaders view Agnew as their secret
weapon in the fall elections and see their chances of
gaining control of Congress enhanced by his presence on
the campaign trail. If one finds all this hard to believe,
the ivory tower complex and association with "effete
snobs" may well account for it.

'No Knock' Passes
A statute permitting federal agents to enter a home
without warning or identification if they believe narcotics
would be destroyed inside has been passed by the Senate.
The 70 to 15 vote on Tuesday followed a three day
debate on the provision which will be added to the omnibus
drug bill being prepared. Under the new statute, agents
suspecting the probable destruction of narcotics by parties trying to escape arrest are entitled to a "no-knock"
warrent by a judge.
In addition to giving agents power to break into a home,
it also could be used in raids on offices of doctors under
suspicion of illicit possession of narcotics. Michigan
Senator Griffin pointed out that 29 states have similar
provisions and that there is no danger of unconstitutionality.
Iowa Senator, Howard Hughes introduced one amendment to require the HEW Secretary's opinion before the
Attorney-General could classify a drug and another to
cut penalties for possession and distribution of marijuana.
Perhaps the general attitude in the Senate was expressed by Senator Dodd who warned that "the hoodlums and
dope peddlers are watching us" to see "if we mean
business."

appeared this week when South Carolina Governor Robert
McNair vowed compliance with the Supreme Court's
ruling on immediate desegregation of public schools
By so doing, he broke ranks with other Southern Gover'
nors, such as Florida's Kirk, who have been largelY

Claiming that "we must adjust to new circumstances,"
McNair promised to oppose attempts by parents to close
down schools rather than desegregate. Citing the examples of Little Rock, Mississippi and Alabama, the
Governor said that they have seen what defiance of the
lawful record of which they are proud.
In a half-hour speech to his constituents, McNair was
most adament in his refusal to compromise the qualitY
of the educational system. "We don't want to bring UP
another generation of illiterates."

HEW Veto Sustained
Sustaining President Nixon's veto of the Congressional
increase of $1.1 billion in the health, education and anti'
poverty appropriations bill, the House of Representatives
Wednesday offered proof of Nixon's political strength.
Nixon weilded his power for the first time last MondaYr
by vetoing a $1 billion appropriation for Health, Education and Welfare.
Claiming that the government's estimated $198 billion
dollar budget was already $5.1 billion more than his
original budget of last April, the President denounced
the "controllable increase" in the health, education, and
anti-poverty measure as "untimely, misdirected, and
inflationary."
The measure was to have provided operation funds for
the Department of Labor, Department of Health, Education, and Welfare, and the Office of Economic Opportunity.
Congress now must decide whether to produce a neW
appropriations bill or authorize continued spending on
the organizations at the current rate.
Nixon rationalized the veto by arguing that he could
not let pass a measure, however worthy its objectives,
that threatened his anti-inflationary efforts and "failed
to target the scarce resour es of the Federal Government in ways I can accept in this period of budget
stringency."
